args:
Nedrick's goals are twofold: Destroy the being
that sealed Bahamut and created the false
world, and reveal the truth to all. Knowing it to
be true that some history has been concealed,
Zethia agrees to dispel the barrier.
The child was born and afflicted with\nwyrmscale. His condition swiftly worsened,\nculminating in his untimely death.
A substitute for the child was made and\nreplaced under a veil of strictest secrecy,\nand his corpse was claimed by a faerie.
His soul would return to mana, and his\nbody would be used and consumed in\nshapeshifting research.
That was to be the entirety of the child's\nshort life—which is to say MY life.

But when I found myself adrift in a place
where my own consciousness was as
indistinct as the haze over a flame, I heard
someone call out to me.
And wholly on instinct, I answered.
At that moment, life flooded back to me.\nAnd as it did so, I realized that something\nlay dormant within me.
Only later—much, much later—did I\nrealize that dormant force was Bahamut.
Then you're saying it was Bahamut's\npower that gave you life once more?\nBut what of the wyrmscale?
My body, now replete with the power of\nthe dragon, dispelled the disease as\neasily as one might swat a fly.
But though I had survived, there was no\nplace left for me in the human world,\nand so I was raised in the Faerie Kingdom.
And now you know my history.
How were you able to make a pact with a\ndragon if you were yet too young to speak?
Dragons will only form pacts with those\nwhose power they have acknowledged.
I cannot begin to imagine one seeking\npartnership with a newborn whelp.
It must have been an unavoidable choice\nfor Bahamut.
The Wyrm of Genesis had long been sealed\naway in the otherworld, seeking a body by\nwhich he might return to our reality.
And then he found me: A vessel through\nwhich dragonblood flowed, stationed in the\nworld he longed to return to.
Perhaps he sought a pact, even if by force,\nin order to obtain a vessel that was on the\ncusp of returning to mana.
So when you take in mana...
It is the price of my unequal pact. As you\ncan no doubt imagine, Bahamut was an\ninconceivable power to me as a child.
Steeped as I was in the wyrm's power, my\nappearance changed—and even now he\ncontinues to command a toll of mana.
If I ever stop absorbing mana from other\nsources, my body will be ravaged by his\npower and decay in short order.
My father, Finlorda, made it so Nedrick's\nbody could replenish its stores of mana.

He had viewed the boy as merely a lab rat,
but when he saw the child yet lived, he set
about trying to prolong his life. It was an
about-face absolutely befitting the man.
In any event, that is the reason Nedrick is\nable to stand before you now.
And to what end do you seek a new pact\nwith Bahamut, Nedrick?
How could your plans possibly involve the\nvery being that robs you of your mana?
I know better than any the abyssal power\nof the dragon that lurks within me.
Which is why I plan to use that power\ninstead of dispelling it.
I will take Bahamut's anger at having been\nsealed away and turn it into my strength.
For the one who sealed Bahamut and the\nenemy I seek to destroy are the same.
Further, they are the one crafting the\nfiction of this world.
Are you saying that there is someone\nwho has altered the recorded history\nof our world?
Did they hide the truth of the Ilian Church?\nThe birth of the Other? Even the matter of\nmy brother?
It is a difficult notion to suddenly believe\nthat someone could be painting such a\nfar-ranging picture.
In time, you will understand; it is my job\nto drag their existence into light, and I will\nsee this done no matter the cost.
I will defeat them, strip away the\nfalsehood that blankets this world,\nand restore the very concept of truth.
But to do that, I must make a new pact\nwith Bahamut and obtain overwhelming\npower.
I implore you, Zethia. Lend me your aid.\nDispel the barrier.
I haven't forgiven you for what you've\ndone—for the pain you caused my family.
But since then, my perspective on the\nworld has changed.
Since the time she and I acted together...
And I find myself unable to conclude that\nyou are merely telling lies.
So I will do as you ask. I will pray for the\nbarrier to come down.
You have made a wise decision, Zethia,\nand we are grateful for your cooperation.
Do not misunderstand me: I do not trust\neither of you completely.
I still must see for myself what manner of\npeople the pair of you truly are.
Instead of treating my brother as though he\nwere useless, I would have you tell him\neverything you know.
He has a way of thinking about things;\npowerful ideals and thoughts that both\nhe and his comrades believe in.
So listen to him. Really listen.
...If ever there is an opportunity in the\nfuture for the two of us to come face to\nface, I will do as you ask.
Good! Then we have an understanding.
Alas, I fear I must step away for a short\nwhile and buy us a smidgen of time.
I beg you to forgive me for making this\ndecision all on my own, Valyx.
You need not apologize. You made the\ndecision you thought best.
I will accompany you to the summit.\nI wish to see that man's thinking play out\nand discover its validity for myself.
Thank you, Brother. Now if you will excuse\nme, I must get started.
(My decision may be the wrong one...)
(But knowing what I do, I can no longer\ncarry on as I used to.)
I am Zethia, the Auspex so blessed\nby the Goddess Ilia.
I bid thee reveal the unseeable boundary\nof mana that blocks our path.
(I feel it now... The source of this barrier's\npower comes from the Other...)
(And a vestige of that power remains\nfrom when he possessed me.)
(If I use it, I can connect to the barrier.)
